Question:

Answer:
Perfection means fully understanding and knowing without attaining realization. Clearly understanding and knowing is called perfection.
As the Buddha said:
All fear the pain of the staff, none do not cherish their lives;
Extend this to others as a standard, and do not use the stick on sentient beings.

Although it is said that all fear the pain of the stick, beings in the formless realm have no body, and although those in the form realm have bodies, they have no whips or sticks. Among those in the desire realm, Buddhas, wheel-turning sage kings, and those above the Heaven of YÄma all do not fear the pain of the stick;
In order to fear the place where one can obtain the stick, it is said all.
Fulfillment is also like this, not for the sake of seeking realization and attachment to the Dharma, it is said fulfillment.
Furthermore, I have said before:
Do not abandon sentient beings, because of the combination of the wisdom of emptiness that cannot be attained, do not fall into the stage of the Å›rÄvakas.
Question:
From the six perfections up to the three pure faculties, it is only said should be fulfilled;
From here on, why is it that all say if one wishes to attain this matter, one should practice prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ?
Answer:
The teachings of the Å›rÄvakas have a limit and are finite, so it is said to be fully endowed;
From here on, the teachings of the buddhas are profound and immeasurable. Since bodhisattvas have not yet attained them, it is said if one wishes to attain this, one should study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Furthermore, the teachings of the Å›rÄvakas are easy to understand and easy to know, so it is said to be fully endowed;
The teachings of the bodhisattvas and buddhas are difficult to understand and difficult to know, so it is said one should study.
Furthermore, the teachings of the Å›rÄvakas are general characteristics;
They only know suffering, know the causes of suffering, know the cessation of suffering, and know the path to the cessation of suffering.
It is like two kinds of doctors:

The first only knows illnesses, knows the causes of illnesses, knows the cure for illnesses, and knows the medicines to cure illnesses, but does not know all illnesses, does not know all the causes of illnesses, does not know the cure for all illnesses, and does not know all the medicines to cure illnesses.
If they only know how to treat human illnesses, they do not know how to treat the illnesses of animals;
Some can govern one country but not others;
Some can cure dozens of illnesses but do not know all four hundred and four kinds of illnesses.
The causes, cures, and medicines for illnesses are also like this.
Second, they fully understand all four kinds, fully understand medicines, and fully understand illnesses.
Sravakas are like minor doctors who cannot understand everything;
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are like great doctors who do not know what is not an illness and do not recognize what is not medicine.
For this reason, the teachings of the Å›rÄvakas should be complete, and the teachings of the bodhisattvas should be studied.
The Buddha has ten powers.
He knows as it truly is what is possible and what is impossible, the first power.

He knows the various past, future, and present activities and experiences of sentient beings, knows where the activities are created, knows the causes and conditions, and knows the retribution, the second power.
Knowing the various dhyanas, liberations, samadhis, and concentrations, as well as the characteristics of defilement and purity, as they truly are, is the third power.
Knowing the superior and inferior faculties of other sentient beings, as they truly are, is the fourth power.
Knowing the various desires of other sentient beings is the fifth power.
Knowing the various and innumerable natures of the world is the sixth power.
Knowing the characteristics of all paths leading to their destinations is the seventh power.

Knowing various past lives, with their common characteristics and causes, from one to two to up to a hundred thousand eons, at the end of the first eon, I was among those sentient beings with such and such a name, eating this and that, experiencing suffering and pleasure, with a lifespan long or short;
dying there and being reborn here, dying here and being reborn here again;
the name, family, food, suffering and pleasure, and lifespan long or short of those reborn here are also like this, is the eighth power.

The Buddha's heavenly eye is pure, surpassing the eyes of all gods and humans. He sees when sentient beings die and are reborn, whether they are handsome or ugly, large or small, whether they fall into evil realms or good realms, and the karmic causes and conditions they receive.
These sentient beings have accomplished evil bodily actions, evil verbal actions, and evil mental actions, slander sages, have wrong views, and have accomplished wrong views and actions.
For these causes and conditions, when their bodies perish and die, they enter the evil realms and are reborn in the hells.
These sentient beings have accomplished good bodily actions, good verbal actions, and good mental actions, do not slander sages, have right views, and have accomplished right views and actions.
For these causes and conditions, when their bodies perish and die, they enter the good realms and are reborn in the heavens, the ninth power.

Because the Buddha has exhausted all outflows, he has uncontaminated mind liberation and uncontaminated wisdom liberation. In the present Dharma, he himself knows and understands that my births are exhausted, my practice is established, and I have ended future existences. He knows this as it truly is. This is the tenth power.
Question:
These ten powers are not yet attained by bodhisattvas, and cannot be attained by Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas. Why are they being discussed now?
Answer:
Although Å›rÄvaka people cannot attain them, if they hear of the merits of these ten powers, they will think:
The Buddha has such great merits.
They will rejoice and say:
We have great benefits and are not lacking in blessings. We have attained pure faith and entered the path to end suffering.
As for the bodhisattvas, hearing this, they will diligently cultivate the bodhisattva path, and will attain the great merits and fruits such as these ten powers.

Furthermore, there are Å›rÄvaka practitioners and bodhisattvas who cultivate the samÄdhi of mindfulness of the Buddha, not just mindful of the Buddha's body, but mindful of the Buddha's various meritorious qualities and Dharma body.
One should think like this:
The Buddha is called a person of omniscience because he understands all kinds of dharmas.
He is called a person of all-seeing because he skillfully distinguishes and explains all dharmas as they truly are.
He is called an unobstructed person of all-knowing and seeing because he directly knows all dharmas.
He is called a person of great compassion because he treats all sentient beings equally.
Because he has great compassion, he is called a savior of the world.
Because he has come by the true path, he is called a tathÄgata.
Because he is worthy of receiving offerings from all worlds, he is called a person worthy of offerings.
Because he has accomplished non-inverted wisdom, he is called a perfectly enlightened one.
Because he has accomplished morality, concentration, wisdom, and knowledge, he is called one of bright practice.
Because he has attained and does not return, he is called Well-Gone;
Because he knows the general and specific characteristics of the world, he is called Knower of the World;
Because he skillfully expounds the peaceful path that transcends the world, he is called Unsurpassed Trainer;
Because he uses the three kinds of teachings to liberate beings, he is called Teacher of Gods and Humans;
Because he can awaken himself and others from the sleep of afflictions in the entire world, he is called Awakened One;
Because all his aspirations are fulfilled, he is called Virtuous One;
Because he has accomplished the ten powers, he is called Firm Vow;
Because he has attained the four forms of fearlessness, he is called Lion of Humans;
Because he has attained immeasurable and profound wisdom, he is called Great Ocean of Merits;
Because his predictions are unobstructed, he is called Like the Wind;
Because he has no aversion or attachment to anything good or bad, he is called Like the Earth;
Because he burns the firewood of all afflictions, he is called Like Fire;
Because he has completely severed all afflictive habits, he is called one who is fully liberated;
Because he abides in the supreme state, he is called World-Honored One.
Because the Buddha has such merits and virtues, one should recollect the Buddha.
For this reason, if bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas wish to attain the ten powers, four fearlessnesses, and eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha, they should study prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

Among them, there were sentient beings who had doubts:
What kind of power and how many kinds of power do you have that you can perform such inconceivable transformations and benefits?
The Buddha, knowing that the assembly had such doubts in their minds, said:

I have the power of the wisdom of the true characteristics of dharmas. This power has ten kinds. Using these ten kinds of wisdom, I can perform such transformations and creations, and I can also surpass what I create.

Furthermore, the Buddha's disciples have planted good roots for many lifetimes, but due to a few causes of offenses, they fall into non-Buddhist paths.
Non-Buddhists always say:
The Buddha does not truly have the power of merit and virtue. It is the power of magic tricks that deceives people's minds.
The Buddha's disciples who have fallen into non-Buddhist paths have doubts in their minds:
If that is so, the Buddha is not a great person.
In order to eliminate this false slander, it is said:
I truly possess the ten powers and four fearlessnesses in order to liberate sentient beings, and it is not an illusion or deception.
Furthermore, when the bodhisattvas cultivate the bodhisattva path and engage in difficult practices that are hard to accomplish, they may wish to slack off. Therefore, the Buddha says:
By practicing these ten powers, you will attain immeasurable rewards.
It is like the leader of a caravan comforting the merchants, saying:
You should not be tired or lazy, but be diligent and persevering. When you reach the treasure mountain, you will obtain the seven treasures and the wish-fulfilling jewel.
The Buddha is also like this, comforting the bodhisattvas, saying:
Do not be tired or weary, but be diligent and make progress, cultivating the bodhisattva path;
By practicing these ten powers, you will attain immeasurable rewards.
For these various kinds of beneficial causes and conditions, he speaks of the ten powers and so forth.
Question:
The Buddha has immeasurable powers, so why only speak of the ten powers?
Answer:
Although the buddhas have immeasurable powers, they speak of the ten powers in order to save people, which are sufficient to accomplish their work:
Using the power of knowledge of proper and improper conditions, they distinguish and contemplate sentient beings, who can be saved and who cannot be saved.

Using the power of knowledge of the results of actions, they distinguish and contemplate which person has karmic hindrances, which person has retributions hindrances, and which person has no hindrances.
Using the power of knowledge of meditations, liberations, and concentrations, they distinguish and contemplate which person is attached to flavors and which person is not attached to flavors.
Using the power of knowledge of superior and inferior faculties, they distinguish and contemplate the amount of wisdom in sentient beings.
Using the power of knowledge of various aspirations, they distinguish and contemplate the preferences of sentient beings.
Using the power of knowledge of various natures, they distinguish and contemplate the profound intentions of sentient beings.
Using the power of knowledge of the path leading to all destinations, they distinguish and contemplate the doors to liberation of sentient beings.
Using the power of knowledge of past lives, they distinguish the previous origins of sentient beings.
With the power of knowledge of destinies, he distinguishes the good and bad destinies of sentient beings.
With the power of knowledge of the destruction of defilements, he distinguishes and measures sentient beings' attainment of nirvÄá¹‡a.
The Buddha uses these ten powers to liberate sentient beings, discerning without error, all attaining completeness.
Therefore, although the Buddha has immeasurable powers, he only speaks of these ten powers.
Furthermore, the power of the possible and impossible definitely knows that from these causes and conditions come these effects, and within this encompasses the nine powers;
in order to liberate sentient beings, within the first power they are distinguished into nine kinds.
Why is this?
These worldly sentient beings directly see grains coming from seeds but do not know, let alone the causes and effects of the mind and mental factors.
The Buddha thoroughly knows the internal and external causes and effects, and therefore it is called power.

The Buddha knows that these sentient beings are bound by the causes and conditions of karma and afflictions, and are liberated by the causes and conditions of pure meditation, concentration, liberation, and so forth;

This is the light and heavy, deep and shallow, coarse and fine of all sentient beings' three periods of time and three types of karma and afflictions, which the Buddha knows completely, thus called power.
The causes and conditions of all sentient beings' various meditations, liberations, samÄdhis, and their great and small depths of liberation, the Buddha knows completely, thus called power.

Question:
What is the power of knowledge of what is possible and what is not possible?
Answer:

The Buddha knows the definite characteristics of all dharmas, causes and conditions, and fruits. From these causes and conditions, such and such fruits are born. From these causes and conditions, such and such fruits are not born.
Why is it so?
As the Sutra of Many Natures states the characteristics of proper and improper conditions:
It is not proper for a woman's body to become a wheel-turning sage king.
Why is it so?
Because all women are subject to men and lack independence.
If a woman cannot even become a wheel-turning sage king, how much less can she become a Buddha!
If a woman attains liberation and nirvana, it is also due to a man. There is no natural attainment of the Way.
It is not proper for two wheel-turning sage kings to appear in the world at the same time.
Why is it so?
Because the accomplishment of enmity does not exist.
Even two wheel-turning sage kings do not share the same era, how much less two Buddhas!
It is not proper for evil karma to receive a happy retribution;
Evil karma cannot even attain worldly happiness, how much less the happiness of transcending the world!
It is not proper for one of evil conduct to be born in the heavens;
Evil conduct cannot even attain birth in the heavens, how much less nirvana!
With the mind covered by the five hindrances, scattered and distracted, it is impossible to attain nirvana without cultivating the seven factors of awakening.
With the mind covered by the five hindrances, even if one does not cultivate the seven factors of awakening, one cannot attain the path of the hearers, let alone the path of the Buddha!
If the mind is free from hindrances, the path of the Buddha can be attained, let alone the path of the hearers!
Such is the principle of what is possible and what is not, which the Buddha himself explained in the Sutra on the Many Kinds of Beings.
The various scholastic masters rely on these words of the Buddha and further elaborate on what is possible and what is not:

If it is said that the Buddha has faults and transgressions, if the sages and saints seek teachers from non-Buddhist paths, if the sages and saints claim to be Buddhas themselves, if the sages and saints fall into evil paths, if the afflictions to be eliminated through seeing the truth arise again, if the sages and saints conceal their faults, if stream-enterers transmigrate through the twenty-five existences, none of these are possible;
As extensively explained in the Sages' Distinctions.

Those who have committed the five heinous crimes, the five kinds of eunuchs, sentient beings who have fallen into the four evil destinies, people from Uttarakuru, and the retinue of Mara, are obstructed by the three obstacles. If it is said that they can attain the Way, it is impossible.

Those who lightly speak the Dharma, who slight the Dharma and themselves, who break the precepts and are ignorant, if it is said that they can attain the joy of the Dharma in its entirety, it is impossible.
To say oneself that one is a Buddha, and not to repent of the evil of body, speech, and mind, and to wish to see the Buddha;
To not repent of the crime of breaking the Sangha, and to wish to see the Buddha;
To enter right concentration from wrong concentration, to enter indeterminate concentration from right concentration;
To say that there are people who truly attain the Way apart from the Buddha's teachings;
To say that the body that should attain the Way will die, it is impossible.
Apart from the consciousness that arises from causes and conditions, there is no Dharma that goes beyond name and form, it is impossible.
For the Buddha to send a messenger on an errand that is not yet completed, and to obstruct it, it is impossible.
To enter the concentration of loving-kindness, and to die due to other conditions;
Entering the concentration of cessation, being in the path of seeing the truth, and dying, all have no such place.
Harming the Buddha or the Buddha's mother, there is no such place.

The wheel-turning sage king's female treasure, elephant, horse, chief minister of the treasury, and chief minister of the army, if they die in the womb or the mother and child die prematurely, all have no such place.
The people of Uttarakuru, the female treasure, and the Buddha's mother, dying and immediately entering a bad path in the next life, all have no such place.

Ignorance cannot give rise to formations, up to birth cannot give rise to old age and death, there is no such place.
Two minds arise simultaneously;
The five consciousnesses can discriminate and grasp characteristics, either attached or detached;
If the eyes can give rise to bodily actions and verbal actions;
If the eyes can enter meditation, it is impossible.
Only the five consciousnesses continue to arise, not the mental consciousness;

Only the group of five consciousnesses can cognize names, can cognize characteristics, can cognize formless dharmas, can cognize the past and future, can cognize dharmas apart from the three times;

Only in the group of five consciousnesses is there the touch of increase, the touch of clarity, the cultivation of meditation, the acceptance of good precepts or bad precepts, joy or sorrow, the absence of initial thought and sustained thought, and the increase of the faculties, all of which are impossible.
The nose consciousness and the tongue consciousness are obscured and indeterminate;
For ordinary beings, the sixth consciousness being apart from the activities of the self is impossible.
There are innumerable such impossibilities.
The same is true for possibilities.

The Buddha knows what is possible and what is impossible, and he distinguishes and measures those who can be saved and teaches them the Dharma, while for those who cannot be saved he creates causes and conditions.
It is like a good doctor who knows which illnesses can be cured and which cannot be cured.
The knowledge of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas is limited, and because of this limitation, they may try to save those who should not be saved, like ÅšÅ«ra;
Or they may not save those who should be saved, like the ones ÅšÄriputra could not save.
The Buddha has none of this. He is indestructible and invincible, because he knows everything. This is called the first power.

As for the power of knowledge of the results of actions, the actions of body and speech, and the precepts one has received in this life, are also evil actions. The actions that arise day and night follow the arising of sin and merit.
The Buddha briefly explains that these actions are included in three categories, which are called the characteristics of all actions.
The Buddha knows that all sentient beings have actions in the past, and their results are also in the past;

Karma in the present is also like this.
Furthermore, in a wholesome mind, one experiences the retribution of wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate karma;

Furthermore, due to the causes and conditions of pleasant karma, one experiences pleasant retribution; due to the causes and conditions of painful karma, one experiences painful retribution; due to the causes and conditions of neither painful nor pleasant karma, one experiences neither painful nor pleasant retribution.

Due to the causes and conditions of karma with present retribution, one experiences present retribution; due to the causes and conditions of karma with retribution in the next life, one experiences retribution in the next life; due to the causes and conditions of karma with retribution in a later life, one experiences retribution in a later life.

Due to impure karmic causes and conditions, one receives a painful retribution; due to pure karmic causes and conditions, one receives a non-painful retribution; due to mixed karmic causes and conditions, one receives a mixed retribution.
Furthermore, there are two kinds of karma:
Karma that must be experienced, and karma that need not be experienced.
Karma that must be experienced cannot be avoided, and one experiences retribution either in time, or in relation to a person, or in relation to a place.

Waiting for the wheel-turning sage king to appear in a prosperous world, one then receives [the blessings]; this is called waiting for time.
Waiting for a person means the person is the wheel-turning sage king.
Waiting for a place means the place where the wheel-turning sage king appears.
Furthermore, this karma that must be experienced does not depend on skills or merits, whether good or bad, it comes by itself without seeking.
For example, when one is born in the heavens, blessings and happiness come by themselves;
When one is in hell, suffering and evil pursue one by themselves.
It does not depend on conditions, because this karma is deep and heavy.

Like Bakkula, who was thrown into fire, boiling water, and water by his stepmother but did not die.

Like the Buddha traveling to various countries, although he went forth and begged for alms, he did not need offerings, yet five hundred carts loaded with the king's food, rice growing in leaves, and a hundred flavors of soup were provided.
Such good and evil karmas must be experienced.
The rest may not necessarily be experienced.
In the desire realm, one experiences the results of three kinds of karmas:
karmas resulting in pleasant feelings, karmas resulting in painful feelings, and karmas resulting in neither painful nor pleasant feelings.
In the form realm, one experiences the results of two kinds of karmas:

Or, waiting for conditions means that based on these conditions, one can receive the retribution for karma.

For example, in the pond of King Bukalava, a golden lotus with a thousand petals was born, as large as a chariot wheel. Because of this, there was a great assembly of joy and many people went forth and attained the Way.

The Buddha knows when that karma was created, whether in the past, one life, two lives, up to a hundred thousand, ten million lives.
How much of the retribution for that karma has already been received, how much has not yet been received;

Knowing the good and bad things used, namely knives, sticks, orders to kill, etc., killing oneself, sending others to kill;
The other evil karmas are also like this.
Good karmas are also like this, knowing such giving, upholding precepts, and cultivating goodness.

Such are the causes and conditions of good karma.

The causes of meritorious karma are:
If it is due to faith, compassion, respect, meditation, wisdom, good friends, and various other causes of good karma.
These karmas are sovereign, and all gods and humans cannot change these karmic characteristics. They always follow sentient beings through millions of kalpas, like creditors pursuing debtors.
When the conditions for obtaining are complete, they will give rise to karmic retribution;
It is like seeds in the ground, when the conditions of time and place are combined, they will grow.
This karma can cause sentient beings to be reborn in the six realms, faster than an arrow.
All sentient beings have their share of karmic retribution;
It is like the inheritance left by parents, which all their children should have a share of.
When the time for the retribution of this karma arrives, it cannot be stopped, like the fire at the end of a kalpa.
According to the place where sentient beings should be born, they are placed everywhere, like a great king giving official positions to those who are suitable.
When a person's life ends, this karma comes and covers their mind, like a great mountain overshadowing things.
This karma can give various bodies, like a skilled painter creating various images.
If a person uses correct karmic actions, they will receive good rewards;
If they use evil karmic actions, they will receive bad rewards.
It is like a person serving the king, receiving rewards according to their service.
In this way, the characteristics and fruits of various karmic actions are distinguished.
Furthermore, as explained in the Sutra on Distinguishing Karmic Actions, the Buddha told Ananda:
A person who does evil is born in a good place, and a person who does good is born in an evil place.
Ananda said:
How is this so?
The Buddha said:
The evil person's current sinful karma has not yet matured, but the good karma from past lives has already matured. For this reason, even though they do evil now, they are born in a good place.
Or, at the time of death, wholesome thoughts and mental factors arise. For this reason, one is also reborn in a good realm.

As for a person who practices goodness being reborn in an evil realm, the goodness of this life is not yet ripe, while the evil of past lives has already ripened. For this reason, although one practices goodness now, one is reborn in an evil realm.
Or, at the time of death, unwholesome thoughts and mental factors arise. For this reason, one is also reborn in an evil realm.
Question:
The meaning of ripeness and unripeness is possible;
How can the mind of a short period at the time of death surpass the power of actions throughout one's life?
Answer:
Although this mind is of short duration, its power is fierce and sharp, like fire or poison. Although small, it can accomplish great things.
Because the mind at the time of death is decisive and fierce, it surpasses the power of actions for a hundred years;
This last mind is called the great mind, because it is urgent to abandon the body and the faculties.
Just as a person who enters the battlefield, not sparing his life or body, is called brave.
It is like an arhat who abandons this body and thus attains the path of arhatship.
In this way, the various kinds of karmic retribution and transformed retribution should also be understood in the same way.
The disciples of the Buddha only know the karmic retribution of evil karma and the karmic reward of good karma, but they are unable to make such fine distinctions;
The Buddha fully knows this karma and its retribution. His wisdom and power are unobstructed and inexhaustible, and cannot be destroyed. This is called the second power.

The power of knowledge that distinguishes the purity and defilement of dhyÄna, liberation, samÄdhi, and samÄpatti - DhyÄna refers to the four dhyÄnas. The Buddha knows that these dhyÄnas are the auxiliary methods for attaining the path. He knows their characteristics, meanings, sequence, cultivation, whether they are with or without outflows, whether they are of learners or post-learners, whether they are pure or defiled, whether they are with or without taste, and their relative depth and shallowness, etc.
The eight liberations are distinguished in the same way as in the dhyÄnas.
When dhyÄna is mentioned, it includes all the samÄdhis of the form realm;
Speaking of liberation, it encompasses all concentrations.
The perfection of meditation is precisely the various liberations.
Meditation, concentration, samÄdhi, liberation, and meditation are all called concentration, which is the mind not being scattered.
Defilement refers to the various afflictions such as craving, views, and arrogance;
Purity refers to true meditation and concentration, unmixed with the afflictions of craving, views, arrogance, etc., like true gold.

Distinction refers to the single-minded practice and non-single-minded practice, constant practice and non-constant practice, difficult entry and easy entry, difficult exit and easy exit, distinguishing characteristics and general characteristics, reversible treatment and irreversible treatment in the various concentrations.
Reversible treatment is like using loving-kindness for sexual desire, the contemplation of impurity for ill-will, and the discernment of the edge and non-edge for delusion;
Using wisdom to discern the various dharmas in a distracted mind, and using the desire to concentrate the mind in a sunken mind.
If it is not so, it is called irreversible treatment.
In this concentration, one should distinguish the time and place:
If the body is emaciated, this is not the time to practice concentration;
When the Bodhisattva was practicing austerities, he thought:
I cannot now give rise to concentration.
If it is a place with many people, it is also not a place to practice concentration.
Furthermore, the Buddha knows whether this concentration is lost, abiding, increasing, or leading to nirvana.

Furthermore, the Buddha knows whether this person finds it difficult to enter concentration and difficult to emerge from concentration, easy to enter and easy to emerge, easy to enter and difficult to emerge, or difficult to enter and easy to emerge.
The Buddha knows that this person should attain such concentration, and knows that this person loses concentration and experiences the five desires;
The Buddha knows that this person, after experiencing the five desires, regains concentration and attains arhatship based on this concentration.
All such concentrations and liberations are precisely samÄdhis.
This concentration, the Buddha uses his profound wisdom to know exhaustively, it cannot be destroyed, it cannot be surpassed, this is called the third power.
The power of knowledge of the superior and inferior faculties of beings means the Buddha knows whether beings have sharp faculties, dull faculties, or middling faculties.
Sharp wisdom is called superior, dull wisdom is called inferior.
The Buddha uses this power of knowledge of superior and inferior faculties to distinguish all beings as having sharp faculties, middling faculties, or dull faculties.
This person with such faculties can only attain the first fruit in this life and cannot attain the others;
this person can only attain the second, third, or fourth fruits.
This person can only attain the first concentration, this person can only attain the second, third, or fourth concentrations, up to the concentration of cessation is also like this.
This person will realize timely liberation, this person will realize timely liberation.
This person can attain the foremost among the Å›rÄvakas;
Such a person can attain the foremost position among pratyekabuddhas;
Such a person is fully endowed with the six perfections and can attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Having understood this, [the Buddha] may give a brief teaching for liberation, or an extensive teaching for liberation, or a brief and extensive teaching for liberation;
Or he may teach using gentle words, or harsh words, or both gentle and harsh words.
The Buddha also distinguishes that this person has remaining faculties that should be allowed to increase the faculty of faith;
This person should be allowed to give rise to the faculties of vigor, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom.

This person enters the stage of right [attainment] using the faculty of faith, this person enters the stage of right [attainment] using the faculty of wisdom.ğŸ”½This person has sharp faculties but is obstructed by afflictions, like Aá¹…gulimÄla and others.
This person has sharp faculties and is not obstructed by afflictions, like ÅšÄriputra, MaudgalyÄyana, and others.
Knowing that the faculties are dull but without obstruction, like CÅ«á¸apanthaka;
There are those with dull faculties who are restrained.
Knowing that this person's faculties are dull in terms of the views to be eliminated, but sharp in terms of the thoughts to be eliminated;
The thoughts to be eliminated are dull, but the views to be eliminated are sharp.
This person's faculties are all the same in being dull or sharp, this person's faculties are all not the same in being dull or sharp.
This person's past causes are powerful, this person's present conditions are powerful.
This person desires to be bound but attains liberation, this person desires to be liberated but attains bondage.
For example, Angulimala, who wanted to kill his mother and harm the Buddha, attained liberation.
Like a certain bhiká¹£u who attained the four dhyÄnas, due to his increased arrogance, he fell back into hell.

Knowing that this person will definitely fall into the evil paths, this person is difficult to escape, this person is easy to escape, this person will escape quickly, this person will escape after a long time.
In this way, he completely knows all the superior and inferior faculties of sentient beings, and none can destroy or surpass them. This is called the fourth power.
The power of knowledge of various desires of sentient beings means:
Desires refer to faith, fondness, and enjoyment.
Fondness for the five desires, like Sundarananda and others;
Fondness for fame, like Devadatta and others;
Fondness for worldly wealth and benefits, like SumÄgadhÄ and others;
Fondness for leaving the household life, like Yasa and others;ğŸ”½Fondness for faith, like Vakkalin and others;
Fondness for upholding precepts, like RÄhula and others;
Fondness for giving, like ÅšyÄmÄvatÄ« (Buddha's aunt and foster mother);
Buddha's paternal aunt and the mother who raised him;
Fondness for ascetic practices and seclusion, like MahÄkÄÅ›yapa;
Fondness for sitting in meditation, like Revata and others;
Fondness for wisdom, like ÅšÄriputra and others;
Fondness for extensive learning, like Ä€nanda and others;
Fondness for knowledge of the Vinaya, like UpÄli and others.
Thus, the Buddha's disciples each have their own preferences.
Ordinary people also each have their own likes:
Some delight in sexual desire, some delight in anger.
Furthermore, the Buddha knows that this person has much desire, much anger, and much delusion.
Question:
What are the characteristics of much desire, much anger, and much delusion?
Answer:
As explained in the Chan scriptures, the characteristics of the three poisons should be explained in detail here.

Having known these characteristics, the method of impurity is used to treat a person with much sexual desire, the method of kindness is used to treat a person with much anger, and the method of causes and conditions is used to treat a person with much delusion.
In this way, according to what is to be said, the Dharma is taught. That is to say, according to the mind, it is taught like a boat going with the current;
Evil desires are taught with harsh words, like using a wedge to remove a wedge.
In this knowledge of desires, the Buddha fully knows without being destroyed or surpassed. This is called the fifth power.
As for the power of knowing natures, the Buddha knows the various different natures in the world.
Nature is called accumulated habits, and characteristics arise from nature. Desire follows nature to create actions;
Sometimes nature arises from desire, and by cultivating desire, nature is formed.
Nature refers to the profound mind for doing things, and desire refers to arising in accordance with conditions. This is the distinction between desire and nature.
The various distinctions in the world means each nature and many natures, immeasurable and innumerable. This is called the distinctions in the world.
There are two kinds of worlds:
The world of the physical world and the world of sentient beings.
Here, only the world of sentient beings is discussed.

The Buddha knows the natures of sentient beings like this, their desires like this, where they come from, whether they have accomplished good roots or not, whether they can be saved or not, whether they are determined or not, whether they are certain or not, what practices they engage in, where they are born, and what stage they are in.

Furthermore, the Buddha knows the various natures and characteristics of these sentient beings, namely, according to their inclinations, such places are abundant, such are noble, such are their profound intentions, such are their desires, such are their actions, such are their practices, such are their afflictions, such are their rituals, such are their concentrations, such are their deportments, such are their knowledges, such are their views and thoughts;
such are the afflictions that have arisen, and such are the afflictions that have not yet arisen.

According to what one is attached to, desire arises; according to desire, the mind becomes defiled; according to defilement, one moves towards; according to movement, one values; according to valuing, one always contemplates; according to contemplation, there is discourse; according to discourse, one always remembers; according to memory, one acts; according to action, one creates karma; according to karma, there is retribution.
Furthermore, using this knowledge of various natures, the Buddha knows which sentient beings can be liberated and which cannot;
which can be liberated in this world and which in the next world;
Some are to be liberated immediately, some are to be liberated at another time;
Some are to be liberated in the present, some are to be liberated without being seen;
Some are to be liberated by the Buddha, some are to be liberated by the Å›rÄvakas, some are to be liberated together;

Some are definitely to be liberated, some are definitely not to be liberated;ğŸ”½Some are to be liberated by brief teachings, some are to be liberated by extensive teachings, some are to be liberated by brief and extensive teachings;
Some are to be liberated by praise, some are to be liberated by subduing;
Some are to be liberated by welcoming, some are to be liberated by abandoning;
Some are to be liberated by subtle dharmas, some are to be liberated by coarse dharmas;
Some are to be liberated by harsh words, some are to be liberated by gentle words, some are to be liberated by both harsh and gentle words.
This is wrong view, this is right view;
This is attachment to the past, this is attachment to the future;
This is attachment to annihilation, this is attachment to permanence;
This is attachment to the view of existence, this is attachment to the view of non-existence;
This is desire for rebirth, this is disgust with rebirth;
This is seeking wealth and status, this is attachment to thick wrong views;
This is saying there are no causes and conditions, this is saying there are wrong causes and conditions, this is saying there are right causes and conditions;
This is saying there is no karma, this is saying there is wrong karma, this is saying there is right karma;
This is saying there is no seeking, this is saying there is wrong seeking, this is saying there is right seeking;
This values self, this values the five desires, this values gaining profit, this values food and drink, this values speaking of amusing things;
This enjoys the crowd, this enjoys busyness, this enjoys seclusion;
This mostly practices craving, this mostly practices views;
This likes faith, this likes wisdom;
This should be guarded, this should be abandoned;
This values upholding precepts, this values dhyÄna concentration, this values wisdom;
This is easily enlightened, this is enlightened through lecturing;
This can be guided, this understands through every phrase;
This has sharp faculties, this has dull faculties, this has middling faculties;
This is easy to escape and easy to pull out, this is difficult to escape and difficult to pull out;
This fears sin, this is a grave sin;
This fears birth and death, this does not fear birth and death;ğŸ”½This has much desire, this has much anger, this has much delusion;
This has much desire and anger, this has much desire and delusion, this has much anger and delusion, this has much desire, anger, and delusion;
This has thin afflictions, this has thick afflictions;
This has few defilements, this has many defilements;
This covers wisdom, this has a robe of wisdom, this has vast wisdom;

This person well knows the characteristics of the five aggregates, the twelve sense fields, the eighteen elements, the twelve links of dependent arising, what is possible and what is impossible, suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path;
He well knows entering concentration, emerging from concentration, and abiding in concentration.
Furthermore, the Buddha knows:
These are beings of the desire realm, these are beings of the form realm, these are beings of the formless realm;
These are hell beings, animals, hungry ghosts, humans, and gods;
whether born from eggs, from wombs, from moisture, or spontaneously;ğŸ”½whether having form or formless;
whether having perception, without perception, or neither;
whether short-lived or long-lived;

whether ordinary beings who have not yet separated from desire, or ordinary beings who have separated from the desire of the lower realms but not from the desire of the dhyanas, and so forth, up to neither perception nor non-perception;
whether on the path of progress, or having attained the fruits;
whether pratyekabuddhas, or buddhas with unobstructed liberation.
In this way, there are various distinctions:

the five destinies, the four modes of birth, the three groups, provisional names, hindrances, assemblies, sense bases, and elements, wholesome roots, unwholesome roots, various bonds and afflictions, stages, karmic fruits, those who can be liberated and those who cannot, cessation, and distinctions of knowledge.
By means of these various distinctions, one knows the various different natures of the world and attains unobstructed liberation.
The Buddha knows all these various differences, and no one can destroy or surpass this, which is called the sixth power.
The power of knowledge of all paths and destinations.
Some say:
Karma is the path.
Why is it so?
Because of karma, one goes through the five paths.
There is karma that can cut off, and karma that can reach, namely the three noble paths and pure thoughts.
Therefore, all karmas are the paths to all destinations.
Furthermore, some say:
The five discernments, five knowledges, and three samadhis (Skt. dhyÄna)
The five factors of the pure samadhi dwell in all places, benefiting and accomplishing things.
Some also say:
The fourth dhyana is it.
Why is it so?
Because the fourth dhyana is the destination of all samadhis.
As it is said in various sutras:
This wholesome mind, concentrated mind, unconfused mind, and focused mind all enter the fourth dhyÄna.
Furthermore, some say:
Just as the mindfulness of the body is the path that leads to the destination, it is the basis for the benefits of all paths.
Some people say:
All noble paths are used to attain the benefits according to one's wishes through these noble paths.
There are also those who discuss it and say:
All good paths, all evil paths, and all noble paths each know the destination of the various paths.
As it is said in the Hair-Standing Upright SÅ«tra.
The Buddha thoroughly knows without being able to be destroyed or surpassed, this is called the seventh power.
The power of knowledge of past abodes - there are three kinds of past abodes:
There is spiritual power, there is illumination, and there is power.
Ordinary people only have spiritual power, and Å›rÄvaka disciples also have both spiritual power and illumination, while the Buddha also has spiritual power, illumination, and power.
Why is it so?
Ordinary people only know the past lives they have experienced, but do not know the continuity of the causes and conditions of karma;
Therefore, ordinary people only have spiritual powers but not wisdom.
Because the disciples of the Buddha know the truth of accumulation, they clearly know the continuity of the causes and conditions of karma;
Therefore, the disciples of the Buddha have both spiritual powers and wisdom.

If the disciples of the Buddha attained the knowledge of past lives as ordinary people, and in the path of seeing the truth, they knew the causes and conditions of accumulation, and attained the eighth undefiled mind to sever the view of self, then their spiritual powers would transform into wisdom.
Why is this?
Wisdom is called the root of seeing.

If the disciples of the Buddha first attained the holy path, and later gave rise to the knowledge of past lives, they would also know the power of the causes and conditions of accumulation, and their spiritual powers would transform into wisdom.
Question:

If the Buddha, when he was originally a bodhisattva, first attained the knowledge of past lives, and if bodhisattvas are free from the afflictions of the sphere of nothingness and later enter the holy path, why did the Buddha say, I attained the first illumination in the first watch of the night?
Answer:
This is not illumination. If the Buddha was in the assembly and said, I attained this illumination at that time,
he would show to the assembly and say:
This illumination was attained in the first watch of the night.
It is like when a king has a son before becoming king, and later when asked:
When was the prince born?
He answers:
The prince was born at such and such a time.
At the time of his birth, he was not yet king, but because he is now king, he takes him as his prince and says:
The prince was born at that time.
The Buddha is also like this. When the knowledge of past lives arises, at that time it is not yet illumination, but is only called a supernormal power;
in the middle watch of the night, he knows the causes and conditions of accumulation, so the supernormal power transforms into illumination;
later, in the assembly, he says:
I attained this illumination in the first watch of the night.
Asked:
The meanings of penetration and illumination are like this, what are the powers?
Answered:
The Buddha uses this illumination to know his own body and sentient beings, the causes and conditions of past lives in immeasurable and boundless worlds, and knows them all, this is called power.
This is called the eighth power.
As for the power of knowledge of birth and death, the Buddha uses his heavenly eye to see the places of birth and death of sentient beings.
Ordinary people, using this heavenly eye, at most see the four continents;
ÅšrÄvaka disciples, at most see the small chiliocosm sideways, and see it all above and below.
Asked:
The king of MahÄbrahmÄ Heaven can also see the chiliocosm, what is the difference?
Answered:
The king of MahÄbrahmÄ Heaven, standing in the chiliocosm, sees it all;
If he stands on the edge, he does not see the other places.
The disciples are not like this. Wherever they stay, they always see a thousand worlds.
Pratyekabuddhas see a hundred thousand worlds, and Buddhas see innumerable and boundless worlds.

The heavenly eye and knowledge of ordinary people are also like this. They are only able to see existing things, and cannot see rebirth according to the causes and conditions of karma, as explained in the chapter on past lives.
Furthermore, the foremost among those who have attained the heavenly eye among humans is Aniruddha. His heavenly eye is half-head pure, created from the four great elements of the form realm.
The Buddha's heavenly eye is completely pure, created from the four great elements.
This is the difference.
Furthermore, the disciples attain the heavenly eye within the samÄdhi in which they abide, and within that samÄdhi they are able to see:
Whether it is a samÄdhi with initial and sustained thought, a samÄdhi without initial thought but with sustained thought, or a samÄdhi without initial and sustained thought.
The Buddha sees all that he wishes to see, abiding in whatever samÄdhi he enters.

If one attains the heavenly eye based on the samÄdhi of no perception and no observation, and enters the samÄdhi of perception and observation, or the samÄdhi of no perception and only observation, one can also see.
Moreover, when a Å›rÄvaka uses this heavenly eye to see, the heavenly eye ceases if the mind enters other samÄdhis.
But the Buddha is not like this. Even if the mind enters other samÄdhis, the heavenly eye does not cease.
This wisdom thoroughly knows the destinies of birth and death of all sentient beings, and is indestructible and invincible. This is called the ninth power.
As for the power of knowledge regarding the destruction of contaminants,
a question is asked:
The wisdom and discernment of the nine powers are different, but the destruction of contaminants is the same. What differences are there between all Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas?
An answer is given:
Although the destruction of contaminants is the same, the wisdom and discernment are greatly different.
For a Å›rÄvaka of utmost power, the bonds to be eliminated through contemplation are eliminated in three stages: the stage of arising, the stage of abiding, and the stage of cessation;
The Buddha is not like this, when the period of one life is over, he completely cuts them off.
The Å›rÄvaka when the bonds and afflictions to be eliminated by seeing the truths arise, he eliminates them; those to be eliminated by contemplation are extinguished in three periods.
The Buddha does not distinguish between those to be eliminated by seeing the truths and those to be eliminated by contemplation.
When the Å›rÄvaka first enters the holy path, entering is different from penetrating.
The Buddha in one mind both enters and penetrates, in one mind attains omniscience, in one mind destroys all obstacles, in one mind attains all the Buddha's teachings.
Furthermore, the Å›rÄvakas have two kinds of liberation:
liberation from afflictions and liberation from the obstacles of dharmas.
The Buddha has liberation from all afflictions and also liberation from all the obstacles of dharmas.
The Buddha naturally attains wisdom, while the Å›rÄvakas attain it by practicing according to the path of teachings.
Moreover, some say:
If the Buddha uses his wisdom to eliminate the afflictions of all sentient beings, his wisdom is neither dull nor diminished.
It is like a red-hot iron ball placed on a small piece of cotton. Although it burns the cotton, the heat of the fire is not diminished;
The Buddha's wisdom is also like this. It burns all afflictions, and the power of wisdom is not diminished.
Furthermore, the Å›rÄvakas only know to end their own outflows;
The Buddhas know to end their own outflows, and also know to end the outflows of others, as explained in the Pure SÅ«tra.

Furthermore, only the Buddha knows the distinctions in the minds of sentient beings, the ninety-eight latent afflictions and one hundred ninety-six entanglements. Apart from the Buddha, there is no one who knows this.

The Buddha alone knows the nature of severing those many fetters in the Dharma cognition of suffering and inferential cognition of suffering, and so forth, up to the inferential cognition of the path;
It is the same in the nine paths of liberation that are eliminated through contemplation.
The Buddha fully knows all such matters of all sentient beings;
If the Å›rÄvakas know a little and speak a little, it is all in accordance with the Buddha's words.
The Buddha's power of wisdom in ending outflows is indestructible and invincible, this is called the tenth power.
Question:
Which of these ten powers is the most supreme?
Answer:
Each is great in its own function, just as water can moisten and fire can burn, each has its own power.
Some say:
The first power is the greatest, because it can encompass the ten powers.
Some say:
The power of ending outflows is the greatest, because it accomplishes tasks and attains nirvana.
The treatise says:
These ten powers all take unobstructed liberation as their root and unobstructed liberation as their superior.
Question:
If these ten powers are exclusively the Buddha's affairs, and no disciples in this world can attain them, why did the Buddha speak of them?
Answer:
In order to cut off people's doubts about the ten powers, to make those without wisdom firmly resolve in their minds, and to delight the fourfold assembly, saying:
Our great teacher alone possesses such power, which is not shared by all sentient beings.
Moreover, the non-Buddhists said:
The Å›ramaá¹‡as of the Gautama clan always dwell in places of tranquility, their wisdom has shrunk.
For this reason, he uttered sincere words:
I am fully endowed with the ten kinds of spiritual powers and the four forms of fearlessness;
In the great assembly, I speak with perfect wisdom, teaching and transforming sentient beings, like the lion's roar, turning the wheel of the Dharma, which no non-Buddhists, gods, or humans can turn.
In order to stop this slander, he spoke of the ten powers.
Question:
Even one aspect of wisdom of a good person should not be praised, let alone the one who is selfless and unattached praising his own ten powers?
As it is said:
Praising oneself, disparaging oneself, praising others, and disparaging others - these four kinds,
The wise do not engage in.
Answer:
Although the Buddha is without self and without attachment, he has immeasurable powers. Out of great compassion to save sentient beings, he only speaks of the ten powers, not to praise himself.
It is like a good merchant leader who sees evil bandits deceiving other merchants by showing them the wrong path;
the merchant leader, out of pity, tells the other merchants:
I am a truthful person. Do not follow the deceivers!
It is also like the evil doctors and so forth deceiving the sick. The good doctor, out of pity, tells the many sick people:
I have good medicine that can cure your illness. Do not trust the deceivers and bring suffering upon yourselves!
Moreover, the Buddha's merits are profound and far-reaching. If the Buddha does not speak of them himself, no one knows them;
if he speaks a little for sentient beings, the benefit is very great.
For this reason, the Buddha himself speaks of the ten powers.
Furthermore, for those who can be saved, he must speak for them. Among what should be spoken, he should speak the ten powers in order;
If he did not speak, they would not be able to cross over, and therefore he spoke himself.
It is like when the sun and moon rise, they do not think:
We illuminate the world, and we will become famous!
When the sun and moon rise, they naturally become famous.
The Buddha is also like this. He does not think to speak of his merits in order to become famous.
The Buddha's pure speech expounds the Dharma, and his radiance breaks through the ignorance and darkness of sentient beings, naturally bringing great fame.
For this reason, the Buddha speaks of his ten powers and other merits himself, without fault.
Power means being able to accomplish something:
Using these ten kinds of powerful increased wisdom, he is able to defeat the debaters;
Using these ten kinds of powerful increased wisdom, he is able to expound the Dharma well;
Using these ten kinds of powerful increased wisdom, he is able to subdue those who are not in accord;
Using these ten kinds of powers to increase wisdom, one attains mastery over all dharmas, like a great king who has mastery over his ministers and the great assembly.
